data.title: Golden moments from a Jubilee year to remember
data.meta_description: The Union flag was flying, and champagne corks were popping, in Borehamwood for the Queen's Golden Jubilee celebrations. Protesters marched through…
data.text:
JANUARY: Pensioners and residents campaigned to save the Borehamwood Care Village, in Cardinal Road, after its owner, Assured Care Centres, said it wanted to sell the site to property developer Bryant Homes. Hertsmere Council officers asked Borehamwood's teenagers what facilities they would like to see provided in the town. Most wanted a youth club, skate park and singing lessons. Irish cinema operator Omniplex Holdings agreed to reopen the cinema at The Point in Shenley Road. Hertfordshire County Council unveiled plans to sell off the Maxwell Park Community Centre in Elstree Way, causing anger and frustration amongst residents. Rabbi Alan Plancey, from Borehamwood United Synagogue, met the Pope during a trip to Italy. Melrose Avenue campaigners celebrated after Hertsmere politicians said a new road should be built to serve a planned 277-home housing estate at the former Fire Research Station.

FEBRUARY: Hundreds of Borehamwood Care Village campaigners marched through Shenley Road. The service set up to find social housing for homeless people in Hertsmere was described as one of the worst in the country by a Government report. Elstree film-maker John Wilcox died, aged 81. Residents called for police protection after gangs between 60 and 70 drunken teenagers kept gathering in Eldon Avenue and vandalising property. A freak snowstorm caused confusion in Shenley Road. Ridgehill Housing Association unveiled plans for a £20million pound redevelopment of Stratfield Road, creating new homes for around 600 residents.

MARCH: A rat was beaten to death in front of dozens of stunned children at the McDonalds restaurant in Shenley Road. Government statistics revealed that, while Borehamwood was home to the four most deprived wards in Hertfordshire, Aldenham was the most affluent ward in England. Borehamwood Care Village campaigners were delighted after 102-year-old resident Rose Cottle took a petition to Downing Street. The home's owner caved in the next week, and promised not to sell to Bryant Homes.

APRIL: Traders in Borehamwood warned that shoplifters were targeting the town, because they knew shopkeepers would probably not report incidents to the over-stretched police. Travellers moved into Tempsford Playing Fields in Borehamwood and left a trail of destruction. A multi-millionaire from Radlett was temporarily blinded by robbers who stole his £75,000 Mercedes car. Tory Party Leader Iain Duncan Smith visited Borehamwood Care Village.

MAY: Hertsmere Council's ruling Conservative group made a significant gain when Sandra Parnell was elected in Borehamwood's Hillside ward, the first Tory to win a seat in the town since 1976. The Tories gained two extra seats in the elections. The new Big Brother house at Elstree Film and Television Studios was unveiled to the press. Police officers and firefighters from Borehamwood faced the worst horrors of their careers as they helped to deal with a train crash at Potters Bar railway station. Mayor of Elstree and Borehamwood Martin Heywood joined the Conservative Party, after resigning from Hertsmere Borough Council's Labour Group. Weeks later Ernie Butler took over as town mayor, and Stuart Nagler took over as Mayor of Hertsmere. Travellers moved onto a field in Woodcock Hill, causing fury amongst nearby residents.

JUNE: Hundreds of people across Borehamwood attended street parties to celebrate the Queen's Golden Jubilee. Elstree and Borehamwood Rotary Club celebrated its 60th anniversary. Former England and Chelsea footballer Dennis Wise was left fuming when burglars stole FA Cup medals and England caps from a house in Radlett. Parents in Radlett started a campaign to save Wall Hall Nursery school, when the county council said it wanted to close it down. Elstree and Borehamwood Town Council's two-week Town Festival, which kicked off with a colourful parade, was a great success. The festival's events were enjoyed by thousands.

JULY: A group of 15 children from Grodno, a town in Belarus contaminated by radiation from Chernobyl, enjoyed a month-long visit to Radlett, organised by the Radlett and Bushey Reform Synagogue. Borehamwood's fire and police stations held open days, drawing in hundreds of visitors. Mayor of Elstree and Borehamwood Ernie Butler met stars at the Elstree Film Evening, held at the BBC Elstree Centre. An Elstree couple were left heartbroken when burglars stole their only videotape of their son's first few months. Kate Lawler emerged as the winner of Big Brother 3, and was watched by 8.5million TV viewers and a crowd of 1,000 fans as she stepped out of the house at Elstree Studios. Bus operator London Sovereign branded Leeming Road a no go area for its 292 route, after vandals kept throwing bricks and stones at its buses.

AUGUST: Campaigners hoping to stop building on Woodcock Hill were fuming after Hertsmere councillors said they were thinking about taking the land out of the Green Belt. The council warned that any other decision could be overturned in court. The borough council brought in unpopular new rules for collecting household waste, which said overloaded bins would not be collected. Residents complained of "rubbish mountains", and said the council had created a health risk. Former councillor Dave Button died at the age of 84, after three decades in local politics. A well, thought to date back to Tudor times, was discovered during renovation works at Schopwick Place in Elstree. As the summer holidays wore on vandals attacked Hertswood School, breaking in twice in three weeks, but students enjoyed improved results, with the GCSE and A Level pass rates rising dramatically from the previous year. Burglars took advantage of the hot weather, breaking into nine Borehamwood homes in a single weekend when householders had left windows open. Huge crowds of movie lovers flocked to Elstree Studios for the Lights, Camera, Action! exhibition, which included displays about films such as Star Wars, Indiana Jones and television shows made in Borehamwood such as The Muppets. England cricket captain Nasser Hussain visited Shenley Cricket Centre, to watch the finals of the Sunbank Under-15s Club Championships.

SEPTEMBER: Property company Bryant Homes unveiled plans to demolish the old Gate Studios building in Station Road and replace it with 160 flats, to the dismay of historians, who wanted it preserved, and residents, who warned of traffic problems. Residents at the John Grooms residential home in Whitehouse Avenue, Borehamwood, launched a campaign to increase awareness of the problems faced by disabled people. Plans for the redevelopment of Elstree Way were unveiled by officers at Hertsmere Council, including amphitheatre plazas, marble floors, circular cafes, glass buildings and grassed roof-terraces. Fred Thomas retired after running Borehamwood Irongmongers in Shenley Road, the town's oldest store, for 42 years.

OCTOBER: TV shows Big Brother, Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? and EastEnders, which are made in Borehamwood, won gongs at the National Television Awards. Relations between Tory and Labour Hertsmere councillors reached a new low, when a council meeting descended into anarchy after a Tory councillor was accused of making an indecent gesture at the Labour leader. Crime statistics showed a worrying increase in crime in Borehamwood, with burglaries up 83 per cent, and overall crime up 32 per cent. A programme of works to improve the Farriers Way estate was agreed by residents and politicians, worried by the increase in youth crime on the estate. Trees were uprooted and thrown into cars and houses in Borehamwood and Radlett, during the worst storms for a decade. Father John Woods, from St Teresa's Church in Shenley Road, died, and The Archbishop of Westminster, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Conner, spoke at his funeral.

NOVEMBER: Borehamwood's biggest employer, T-Mobile, announced it was moving almost all of its operations to new headquarters in Hatfield, and taking most of its 2,600 jobs there. Vandals stole a minibus from Hertswood School and set it alight, leading to a backlash against vandalism in Borehamwood. Paratroopers moved into the former Lyndhurst School site, to man Green Goddesses brought in during the firefighters' strike. Celebrities, including Les Dennis and Melinda Messinger moved into the Big Brother house for ten days, in a show watched by millions. Thousands of people attended the town council's fireworks display at Meadow Park. Boreham Wood Football Club celebrated success in qualifying for the FA Cup, but were knocked out in the first round by professional side Torquay United. Remembrance Day parades were well attended in Borehamwood, Radlett and Shenley, despite pouring rain. Eldon Avenue residents complained that drunken teenage hooligans were "making their lives hell" by intimidating people and vandalising property.

DECEMBER: Borehamwood was left in shock after Wayne Trotter, a father-of-one from the Farriers Estate, died after being doused in petrol and set alight. Hertsmere Labour Group leader Frank Ward was ousted as chairman of a committee at the council, but claimed he was a victim of a political campaign against him by the Tories. Borehamwood's primary schools celebrated the best results for years with 17.9 per cent more achieving the required standard in maths at age 11 than the previous year. Hertsmere Council agreed to put £140,000 towards Boreham Wood FC's new synthetic pitch in Meadow Park, to be used by community.
